definition: SMD jumper wire in resistor form.
Oscilloscope probe with 10:1 attenuation.
The frequency at which a filter's output drops to 70.7% of its passband value, corresponding to half power.
Frequency-weighting curve approximating human hearing sensitivity, attenuating low and high frequencies while emphasizing 1–6 kHz.
Signal path that blocks DC and passes only the time-varying component.
How close a measurement reading is to the true value.
A filter using op-amps or other active devices to shape frequency response without inductors.
Oscilloscope probe with a built-in amplifier at the tip, presenting very low capacitance (~1 pF) and high impedance.
Automatic Gain Control — a feedback loop that adjusts gain to maintain constant output amplitude.
Logarithmic capacitance loss over time in Class II and III ceramic capacitors.
Primary bus interconnect on ARM Cortex-M MCUs connecting CPU, memory, and high-speed peripherals.
Unwanted lower-frequency components appearing in a sampled signal when it contains frequencies above the Nyquist frequency.
SI unit of electric current.
A logic gate that outputs 1 only when all inputs are 1.
Frequency expressed in radians per second: ω = 2πf.
Ratio of radiated power to input power; determined by radiation resistance divided by total resistance.
Directivity of an antenna multiplied by its efficiency; measured in dBi (relative to isotropic) or dBd (relative to dipole).
A low-pass filter before an ADC that prevents frequencies above half the sample rate from folding back as false signals.
Secondary peripheral buses (APB1, APB2) on ARM Cortex-M MCUs connecting lower-speed peripherals like UART, SPI, and timers.
Variation in the exact sampling moment of an ADC, introducing timing errors that translate to amplitude errors.
The product of RMS voltage and RMS current, measured in volt-amperes (VA).
A FIFO buffer with independent read and write clocks for cross-domain data transfer.
Property of an operation that completes in a single uninterruptible step at the hardware level.
Instrument feature that automatically selects the measurement range.
Non-destructive reverse breakdown in a diode where carrier multiplication occurs at high electric field.
For circularly polarized antennas, the ratio of major to minor axis of the polarization ellipse.
Transformer converting between balanced and unbalanced impedances for interfacing antennas to transmission lines.
A filter that passes frequencies between low and high cutoff points and attenuates outside that range.
A filter that attenuates a specific range of frequencies while passing those above and below.
A reference circuit exploiting complementary temperature coefficients to produce a temperature-stable output near 1.25 V.
The reduction in overall bandwidth when identical amplifier stages are cascaded.
Embedded firmware that runs without an operating system, managing all scheduling and resource allocation directly.
The condition for sustained oscillation: loop gain ≥ 1 and total phase shift = 360°.
Cortex-M register that selectively disables interrupts below a configured priority level while allowing higher-priority interrupts.
The data rate of a serial interface in bits per second.
Controlling phase and amplitude of signals to multiple antenna elements to steer the radiation pattern.
Angular width of an antenna's main lobe, typically measured at -3 dB half-power points.
Filter response with the best phase linearity and minimal step-response overshoot.
The DC current gain of a BJT, defined as I_C / I_B, varying widely between devices.
IC package with solder balls on the bottom surface instead of pins on the perimeter.
Second-order IIR filter section with 5 coefficients, commonly cascaded to build complex digital filters.
Memory access technique on Cortex-M3/M4 where each bit in a peripheral or SRAM region is aliased to a full 32-bit word for atomic bit manipulation.
The binary configuration file that programs an FPGA.
A bipolar junction transistor — a current-controlled device where small base current controls large collector current.
A two-panel graph showing magnitude (dB) and phase (degrees) versus frequency on a logarithmic scale.
The parasitic diode between source and drain in a MOSFET, conducting when drain voltage drops below source.
Switching power supply topology that produces an output voltage higher than its input.
Small program stored in protected flash that receives, validates, and installs new firmware images for field updates.
Block RAM — dedicated dual-port SRAM blocks in FPGAs.
A path between two nodes in a circuit, carrying a single current.
A four-diode configuration that converts AC to DC by conducting both polarities through two diodes each.
Hardware circuit that monitors supply voltage and asserts reset if it drops below a configured threshold, preventing corrupted execution.
Bit Set/Reset Register on STM32 GPIOs enabling atomic single-bit pin operations without read-modify-write.
Switching power supply topology that produces an output voltage lower than its input.
Switching topology that can produce an output voltage either higher or lower than the input, with inverted polarity in the basic form.
Voltage drop across an ammeter's internal shunt resistor.
Analog filter with maximally flat passband response; the default choice when predictable amplitude behavior is desired.
Filter response with maximally flat passband and monotonic roll-off.
Capacitor placed near an IC's power pins to supply instantaneous current demands and shunt high-frequency noise to ground.
Class I ceramic dielectric.
Message-based differential bus protocol for reliable multi-node communication in noisy environments, using CRC and automatic retransmission.
Extension of classic CAN allowing higher data-phase bit rates (up to 8 Mbps) and larger payloads (up to 64 bytes).
Vintage resistor type made from a solid slug of carbon and binder.
A fast adder technique computing all carries in parallel instead of rippling through stages.
FM bandwidth approximation: BW ≈ 2 × (Δf + f_m), capturing about 98% of the FM signal power.
A two-transistor configuration combining common-emitter with common-base to improve bandwidth and output impedance.
Core Coupled Memory on some STM32 MCUs connected directly to CPU, not accessible by DMA, used for time-critical code.
Clock Domain Crossing — a signal passing between circuits driven by different clocks.
The impedance of a transmission line determined by its geometry and dielectric.
Transient voltage disturbance caused by capacitive coupling from the gate when a MOSFET switch toggles.
A voltage converter using switched capacitors instead of inductors, simpler but lower power than inductor-based converters.
Electrical connection to the equipment's metal chassis or frame.
Filter response with steeper roll-off than Butterworth at the cost of passband ripple.
Fundamental physical limit stating that antenna size, bandwidth, and efficiency cannot all be maximized simultaneously.
Three-port device directing RF energy from one port to the next in sequence; used for transmit/receive isolation.
Protection component (typically a diode or TVS) that limits voltage excursions by conducting when a threshold is exceeded.
Using a diode and capacitor to shift the DC level of an AC signal without changing its shape.
Using diodes or other components to limit signal excursion by conducting when a threshold is exceeded.
The difference in clock arrival time between two points in a system.
A balanced distribution network of buffers ensuring equal clock delay to all flip-flops.
The propagation delay from a clock edge to when the flip-flop output changes.
The gain of a circuit with feedback applied, approximately 1/β when loop gain is large.
A logic family built from complementary NMOS and PMOS transistor pairs, now dominant in digital design.
ARM standard providing unified header files and runtime libraries for Cortex-M peripherals across different vendors.
A BJT amplifier with input at the emitter and output at the collector, providing current gain and high bandwidth.
A BJT amplifier configuration with input at the base and output at the collector, providing voltage gain with phase inversion.
A MOSFET amplifier with input at the source and output at the drain, analogous to common base.
A MOSFET amplifier with input at the gate and output at the drain, analogous to common emitter.
An instrument's or amplifier's ability to ignore voltage that appears equally on both inputs.
A circuit that compares two voltages and outputs a binary high or low result.
Inductor core made from magnetic particles suspended in resin.
Input power level at which device gain drops 1 dB from linear; indicates onset of nonlinear behavior.
Saving one task's CPU registers and stack pointer and loading another's, essential for RTOS multitasking.
PCB traces designed with specific dimensions relative to the ground plane to achieve a target characteristic impedance.
The standard engineering convention: current flows from positive to negative.
Power loss through a passive mixer, typically 5-8 dB for diode ring mixers.
Transmission line with signal trace and ground conductors on the same PCB plane.
Large area of copper on a PCB layer, typically connected to ground or power.
The frequency below which flicker noise exceeds white noise in a device's noise spectrum.
ARM's family of 32-bit processor cores designed for microcontroller use, including M0, M0+, M3, M4, and M7 variants.
SI unit of electric charge.
A register that increments or decrements its value on each clock cycle.
Capacitor in series with a signal path that passes AC while blocking DC.
In a directional coupler, the ratio of coupled port power to input power in dB.
Complex Programmable Logic Device — multiple PLD blocks connected by a programmable routing matrix.
Error detection code computed over data to verify integrity in communication, firmware images, and stored configuration.
Ratio of peak to RMS amplitude; varies by waveform and determines headroom requirements.
The longest propagation delay path between flip-flops, limiting maximum clock frequency.
Distortion in push-pull output stages caused by both transistors being off near the signal's zero crossing.
Unintended signal coupling between adjacent conductors through parasitic capacitance or mutual inductance.
A quartz crystal vibrating at a precise frequency, used as a clock source.
Temperature above which a ferroelectric ceramic's dielectric properties degrade sharply.
A PCB trace intentionally severed, usually as a rework modification.
The frequency at which a filter's response is 3 dB below the passband level.
An edge-triggered memory element that captures D input on a clock edge and holds it.
A latch controlled by a data input and enable signal, transparent when enable is active.
Displayed Average Noise Level — noise floor of a spectrum analyzer at a given resolution bandwidth.
Decibels Full Scale — reference scale in digital audio where 0 dBFS represents the maximum representable digital value.
Power measured in decibels referenced to 1 milliwatt.
Voltage in decibels referenced to 0.775 V (the voltage that produces 1 mW into 600 Ω).
Voltage in decibels referenced to 1 volt.
Loss of capacitance in ceramic capacitors when DC voltage is applied.
Setting the DC operating point of an active device to ensure it operates in the correct region for signal amplification.
Signal path that passes all frequencies including DC.
The resistance of an inductor's winding measured at DC.
Discrete Cosine Transform — real-valued transform used in audio and image compression, more energy-compacting than DFT.
The complement of AND is OR with complemented inputs, and vice versa.
Mathematically removing cable, connector, and fixture effects from a measurement to isolate the device under test.
The interval between turning off one switch and turning on the complementary switch in a bridge circuit to prevent shoot-through.
Hardware delay between one half-bridge output turning off and the complementary output turning on, preventing shoot-through.
Technique for stabilizing noisy digital inputs by sampling multiple times and recognizing transitions only after consistent state.
ARM CoreSight interface providing halt, inspect, and modify access to CPU state through JTAG or SWD.
Reducing sample rate by filtering and downsampling; removes high-frequency content and reduces data rate.
A combinational circuit that activates one of 2^n outputs based on an n-bit input code.
Placing capacitors near IC power pins to supply instantaneous switching current and prevent noise from propagating through the power distribution network.
Difference in propagation time between first-arriving and last significant signal component; causes frequency-selective fading.
Mathematical technique for converting between triangle (delta) and star (wye) resistor network topologies.
A voltage or current source whose value is controlled by another voltage or current elsewhere in the circuit.
A MOSFET that is normally on, conducting with zero gate voltage.
Reducing a component's maximum allowable power, voltage, or current as operating conditions (typically temperature) move away from the rated conditions.
Property that execution meets timing deadlines predictably; hard real-time requires deterministic worst-case behavior.
Insulating material between capacitor plates that determines capacitance, voltage rating, stability, and loss characteristics.
Property of an insulating material affecting electromagnetic wave speed and impedance; also called relative permittivity.
Two matched transistors with tied emitters/sources and a common current source, the fundamental building block of analog ICs.
Bending of electromagnetic waves around obstacles or edges; more pronounced at lower frequencies.
Device separating or combining signals of different frequency ranges into shared ports.
Transmission line component sampling a fraction of signal power from the main path for monitoring.
Ratio of antenna radiation intensity in the maximum direction to that of an isotropic source.
Intentionally added noise before quantization that randomizes quantization error, converting distortion into perceptually preferable noise.
Hardware engine that moves data between peripherals and memory without CPU intervention, essential for high-throughput applications.
The fundamental bench instrument for measuring voltage, current, and resistance.
Differential Non-Linearity — variation in ADC/DAC step size between adjacent codes; DNL > 1 LSB means missing codes.
Adding a low-frequency pole to ensure gain drops below unity before phase accumulates to 360°.
Change in signal frequency due to relative motion between transmitter and receiver.
Dots placed on transformer winding symbols to indicate which terminals have the same instantaneous polarity.
The amount of current a logic output can source or sink.
The minimum input-to-output voltage difference required for a regulator to maintain regulation.
Dedicated multiply-accumulate hardware in FPGAs for signal processing.
Device allowing simultaneous transmission and reception on the same antenna by separating frequency bands.
The fraction of time the main switch is on in a switching regulator, determining the voltage conversion ratio.
Ratio between the largest undistorted signal and the smallest detectable signal, accounting for noise floor and clipping.
The slope of the I-V curve at a specific operating point (dV/dI).
The slight increase in BJT collector current with higher V_CE, caused by base-width modulation.
A BJT parameter (V_A) representing the extrapolated voltage at which collector current would become zero.
Physical connection to the earth, typically through the building's grounding system.
Power dissipated by circulating currents induced in a conductive core by the changing magnetic field.
Non-volatile byte-addressable memory with high endurance (100k–1M cycles), used for configuration storage.
Equivalent area of a receiving antenna that captures incoming wave power; relates to gain via A_e = Gλ²/4π.
Effective Isotropic Radiated Power — equivalent power an isotropic radiator would need to match the actual antenna's field strength.
Polarized capacitor using a liquid or polymer electrolyte to achieve high capacitance density.
The physical movement of electrons from negative to positive.
Analog filter with steepest rolloff for a given order, but with ripple in both passband and stopband.
Electromagnetic Compatibility — ability of a device to function without causing or being affected by interference.
Electromagnetic Interference — unwanted electromagnetic energy disrupting electronic equipment operation.
An unbypassed emitter resistor providing negative feedback that stabilizes gain at the cost of reduced voltage gain.
A BJT buffer with unity voltage gain and low output impedance, also called common collector.
A combinational circuit that converts one-hot inputs to a binary code.
Byte ordering in multi-byte values; ARM Cortex-M is configurable but almost always little-endian.
A MOSFET that is normally off, requiring gate voltage above threshold to conduct.
Actual useful resolution of an ADC after accounting for noise, typically 1–2 bits less than stated resolution.
Graph showing how human hearing sensitivity varies with frequency at different listening levels.
Compensation for frequency-dependent channel loss using transmitter and/or receiver techniques.
A single resistance value that replaces a series, parallel, or complex combination of resistors for analysis purposes.
Using clamping diodes to steer electrostatic discharge current away from sensitive inputs.
Parasitic inductance in a capacitor from its leads, internal connections, and plate geometry.
The effective series resistance inside a capacitor, representing all resistive losses.
ARM CoreSight feature recording every instruction executed for complete instruction trace, requiring a trace-capable debug probe.
Ring buffer where ISRs push events and the main loop dequeues and processes them, decoupling interrupt and application logic.
Error Vector Magnitude — measure of modulated signal quality by distance between ideal and actual symbol positions.
A visual representation of signal quality showing timing and voltage margins at the receiver.
The number of inputs a logic output can drive while maintaining valid logic levels.
Region beyond 2D²/λ from an antenna where the radiation pattern is stable and free-space models apply.
SI unit of capacitance.
A diode optimized for low reverse recovery time, suitable for switching power supply applications.
The portion of the output signal returned to the input through the feedback network.
A frequency-dependent resistive component in series with supply traces to attenuate high-frequency noise while passing DC.
Ceramic magnetic core material made from iron oxide compounds.
Fast Fourier Transform — efficient algorithm computing the DFT in O(N log N) operations instead of O(N²).
Frequency Hopping Spread Spectrum — technique where carrier frequency changes pseudorandomly within a band.
First-In-First-Out hardware buffer on peripherals that stores data temporarily, reducing interrupt frequency.
Capacitor using plastic film as the dielectric.
The number of poles in a filter, determining the asymptotic roll-off rate at 20 dB/decade per pole.
Finite Impulse Response filter computing each output as a weighted sum of current and past input samples; always stable.
Software program running on an embedded device, stored in flash and executed from power-on.
Non-volatile memory storing firmware code and data, requiring erase-then-program cycles for modification.
Stall cycles inserted when CPU clock exceeds flash access speed; must be configured before increasing clock frequency.
Multi-sheet schematic where all sheets exist at the same hierarchy level, connected by net names.
Equal-loudness contours showing that human hearing is most sensitive in the 2–5 kHz range.
Noise whose power spectral density increases at lower frequencies, dominant below the corner frequency.
A node or pin with no defined connection to a voltage source, ground, or driven signal. Floating inputs are susceptible to noise pickup and undefined logic states.
The voltage spike produced when current through an inductor is suddenly interrupted.
Diode placed across an inductive load to provide a safe current path when the driving switch opens.
The BJT operating region where the base-emitter junction is forward biased and collector-base is reverse biased.
The voltage drop across a diode when current flows in the forward direction, typically 0.6-0.7 V for silicon.
Field-Programmable Gate Array — a programmable chip with configurable logic blocks and routing.
Hardware floating-point unit on Cortex-M4F and M7, disabled by default after reset and requiring CPACR configuration.
Most widely used open-source RTOS for embedded systems, running on virtually every MCU with 4 KB or more SRAM.
Concentric circular regions between transmitter and receiver used to predict clearance for unobstructed propagation.
Finite State Machine — a sequential circuit that moves through defined states according to inputs.
A circuit that adds two 1-bit inputs plus carry-in to produce a sum and carry-out.
A rectifier circuit using four diodes in a bridge configuration to convert both polarities of AC to DC.
Reduction in amplifier output gain at high input power due to saturation.
The stability margin in dB between loop gain and 0 dB at the frequency where phase equals 360°.
An unintended rise in gain near cutoff frequency, indicating underdamped response or insufficient phase margin.
Distributing amplification across a signal chain to maintain optimal signal levels above noise floor and below clipping.
Gain-bandwidth product — the product of closed-loop gain and bandwidth, approximately constant for a given op-amp.
Transistor configuration that multiplies two signals; basis of most integrated RF mixers.
A momentary incorrect output caused by different propagation delays through logic paths.
A named electrical connection that spans multiple schematic sheets without explicit wiring.
Efficient algorithm computing a single DFT bin in O(N) operations; useful for single-frequency detection like DTMF.
General-Purpose Input/Output pins configurable by firmware for reading or writing digital signals.
A binary encoding where only one bit changes per count, avoiding multi-bit transition glitches.
Voltage spike on the ground network caused by fast-changing currents flowing through resistive and inductive ground paths.
A continuous copper layer on a PCB dedicated to ground.
The time delay experienced by signal components at a given frequency, the derivative of phase versus frequency.
A driven shield trace at the same potential as a sensitive node, reducing capacitive leakage and coupling.
Hardware Abstraction Layer providing common function calls over vendor-specific register interfaces for portability.
A circuit that adds two 1-bit inputs to produce a sum and carry.
Antenna with two quarter-wavelength conductors fed at the center; reference antenna with 0 dBd gain and ~73 Ω impedance.
A rectifier circuit using one diode to convert one polarity of an AC signal to DC.
Windowing function for spectral analysis with moderate main lobe width and -43 dB sidelobe level.
General-purpose windowing function for spectral analysis with moderate main lobe width and -31 dB sidelobe level.
CPU architecture with separate buses for instructions and data, allowing simultaneous fetch and data access.
Margin between current signal level and the maximum level a stage can handle before clipping, measured in dB.
SI unit of inductance.
SI unit of frequency.
IC power connection that exists in the component model but is not explicitly shown on the schematic symbol.
Schematic organized as a top-level block diagram with each block implemented as a separate sheet.
A filter that passes frequencies above a cutoff and attenuates frequencies below it.
The minimum time data must remain stable after the clock edge for reliable capture.
Duration that a capacitor can sustain a load after the input power is removed.
Energy dissipated in a magnetic core each AC cycle as magnetic domains reverse direction.
Two signals 90° apart in phase; fundamental to SDR and digital communications.
Inter-Integrated Circuit — a synchronous, half-duplex, multi-master serial bus using two open-drain lines.
Synchronous half-duplex 2-wire bus for slow peripherals using open-drain signaling with external pull-ups.
Synchronous 3–4 wire bus for high-quality audio data transfer between ICs.
Intermediate Frequency — lower frequency to which an RF signal is converted for easier filtering and amplification.
Input Third-Order Intercept Point — theoretical input level where third-order intermodulation equals the fundamental.
Infinite Impulse Response filter using feedback; efficient but potentially unstable.
RF frequency that produces the same IF as the desired signal when mixed with the local oscillator.
Generalized resistance for AC circuits, including both resistive (real) and reactive (imaginary) components.
Selecting load impedance to maximize power transfer from a source.
The property of a component that resists changes in current by storing energy in a magnetic field.
Integral Non-Linearity — maximum deviation of an ADC/DAC transfer function from an ideal straight line.
Small current drawn by an op-amp's input terminals, nanoamps for BJT inputs and picoamps for FET inputs.
The impedance presented by a circuit or instrument at its input terminals.
A small DC voltage difference between the inputs of a real op-amp that produces output error in precision circuits.
The large transient current drawn when power is first applied to a circuit, typically caused by charging initially discharged capacitors.
Signal power loss when passing through a component like a filter, cable, or connector.
The product of voltage and current at any specific moment: P(t) = V(t) × I(t).
Degradation of a dielectric material leading to increased leakage current or catastrophic short circuit.
New frequency components generated when multiple signals mix nonlinearly in a circuit.
Increasing sample rate by inserting new samples and filtering; the inverse of decimation.
The method of connecting amplifier stages — AC-coupled (capacitive) or DC-coupled (direct).
An op-amp configuration with input at the inverting terminal through a resistor, gain set by the feedback resistor ratio.
Third-Order Intercept Point — output level where third-order intermodulation product equals the fundamental.
Non-contact temperature measurement tool that reads infrared radiation from a surface.
Unlicensed frequency bands for Industrial, Scientific, and Medical use; includes 915 MHz and 2.4 GHz.
Passive device allowing signal flow in one direction while blocking the reverse; prevents reflections.
Interrupt Service Routine — handler function that executes when an interrupt fires; must be short and non-blocking.
ARM Instrumentation Trace Macrocell sending trace data through the SWO pin, faster than UART logging.
Variation in clock edge timing from cycle to cycle.
A flip-flop with J and K inputs that can set, reset, hold, or toggle.
Random voltage noise generated by thermal motion of electrons in any resistor.
SI unit of energy.
4–5 wire debug and test interface predating SWD, still used on larger processors and FPGAs.
The capacitance of a reverse-biased diode that varies with the applied reverse voltage.
Windowing function with adjustable parameter β to tune the tradeoff between main lobe width and sidelobe level.
A graphical method for simplifying Boolean functions by grouping adjacent truth table entries.
The sum of currents entering a node equals the sum of currents leaving.
The sum of voltage drops around any closed loop equals zero.
Wavelength — physical distance of one complete electromagnetic oscillation; λ = c / f.
Time delay between when a signal enters a system and when the corresponding output appears.
Low-dropout regulator — a linear regulator designed to operate with very small input-to-output voltage difference.
Small, undesired current flowing through a nominally insulating path.
Converting a signal from one voltage level to another when interfacing different logic families.
Linear Feedback Shift Register — generates pseudo-random sequences using XOR feedback.
How much a regulator's output changes per volt of input change.
A circuit that obeys the superposition principle: the response to a sum of inputs equals the sum of the individual responses.
Filter property where all frequencies are delayed by the same amount, preserving waveform shape.
A voltage regulator that maintains constant output by dissipating excess voltage as heat across a series pass element.
Accounting of all gains and losses in a communication path from transmitter to receiver.
Configuration file defining memory layout and section placement for firmware, specifying where flash, SRAM, and code sections reside.
Low-Noise Amplifier — high-gain, low-noise amplifier placed after the antenna to amplify weak signals.
How much a voltage source's output changes per unit of load current change.
The effect of connecting a load to a circuit, which draws current and may change the operating voltage.
Signal generator providing the frequency reference for a mixer in superheterodyne receivers.
Measurement technique that demodulates a signal at a known reference frequency, detecting signals buried far below noise.
Test instrument capturing multiple digital signals simultaneously and displaying decoded protocol information.
A MOSFET designed to be fully on with 3.3 V or 5 V gate drive.
Any closed path through a circuit, traversing one or more branches and returning to the starting node.
Design of the feedback network in a switching regulator to ensure stability across all operating conditions.
The product of forward gain and feedback fraction (T = A × β), determining feedback effectiveness.
Measure of dielectric material loss; higher values mean more energy absorption at RF.
A filter that passes frequencies below a cutoff and attenuates frequencies above it.
Loudness Units Relative to Full Scale — perceptual loudness measurement used in audio mastering and broadcast.
Lookup table — a small memory implementing arbitrary Boolean functions in FPGAs.
Low-Voltage Differential Signaling — a standard for high-speed data and clock distribution.
The energy storage medium in inductors and transformers.
Physical deformation of a magnetic core material caused by the changing magnetic field.
Line code where every bit has a mid-bit transition for guaranteed clock recovery.
Phenomenon where a loud signal makes quieter signals inaudible; includes simultaneous and temporal masking.
Components selected or designed to track each other's temperature coefficient for ratiometric stability.
Circuit of inductors, capacitors, or transmission lines that transforms impedance for maximum power transfer.
Occurs when load resistance equals the source's Thevenin resistance.
A state machine where outputs depend on both current state and current inputs.
Definition of what exists at each address in the MCU's address space — flash, SRAM, peripherals, and reserved regions.
Accessing peripherals through normal memory read/write instructions to specific addresses rather than special I/O instructions.
Microelectromechanical systems microphone, often with PDM output, requiring decimation to produce PCM audio.
Systematic circuit analysis method that applies KVL around independent loops (meshes) and solves for loop currents.
Through-hole resistor type with low noise, tight tolerance, and good temperature stability.
A state where a flip-flop output is indeterminate between HIGH and LOW for an uncertain duration.
The property of some components (especially ceramic capacitors) to generate voltage when subjected to mechanical vibration, due to the piezoelectric effect.
A PCB trace on an outer layer with a ground plane beneath, the most common controlled-impedance structure.
The multiplication of gate-drain capacitance by voltage gain, slowing switching and potentially causing oscillation.
Unit of electric charge commonly used to rate battery capacity.
Multiple-Input Multiple-Output — antenna system using multiple antennas at both ends to increase capacity.
Weakest signal a receiver can detect with acceptable performance; determined by noise floor and required SNR.
Unwanted output frequency produced by a mixer due to intermodulation or harmonic products.
Monolithic Microwave Integrated Circuit — RF IC containing amplifiers, mixers, and passives on a semiconductor substrate.
Varying amplitude, frequency, or phase of a carrier signal to encode information.
Single conductor perpendicular to a ground plane; electrically equivalent to half a dipole.
DAC property that increasing digital codes always produce equal or increasing output levels.
A state machine where outputs depend only on the current state.
A voltage-controlled transistor where gate voltage controls drain current through an insulated gate.
Mean Time Between Failures — average time between metastability-induced failures.
Signal fading from multiple propagation paths arriving with different amplitudes and phases.
A combinational circuit that selects one of several data inputs and routes it to a single output.
RTOS synchronization primitive allowing only one task to hold a resource, supporting priority inheritance to prevent inversion.
Magnetic coupling between adjacent inductors or windings.
AND followed by NOT; a universal gate capable of implementing any Boolean function.
Affordable vector network analyzer covering typically 50 kHz to 1.5 GHz for antenna and circuit measurements.
Region close to an antenna where electromagnetic fields are complex and reactive.
Feedback where the returned signal opposes the input, creating self-correction that stabilizes gain and reduces distortion.
A label applied to a wire or connection in a schematic that replaces physical wire drawings.
An instrument that measures frequency response with both amplitude and phase information.
Highest-priority exception on Cortex-M that cannot be disabled, reserved for critical system faults.
An explicit marker on a schematic indicating that an IC pin is intentionally left unconnected.
Systematic circuit analysis method that applies KCL at each node and solves for node voltages.
A junction where two or more branches meet in a circuit.
A measure of how much noise a circuit adds beyond the thermal noise of its source impedance.
The minimum detectable signal level, limited by the sum of all noise sources in the circuit.
The gain that applies to noise and offset voltage in an op-amp circuit, which may differ from signal gain.
The voltage difference between guaranteed output levels and required input thresholds.
Feedback technique in delta-sigma converters pushing quantization noise to high frequencies where it can be filtered out.
Noise voltage or current per unit bandwidth, typically expressed in nV/√Hz or pA/√Hz.
The approximate or stated voltage under no-load or standard conditions.
An op-amp configuration with input at the non-inverting terminal, gain set by 1 + R_f/R_in.
OR followed by NOT; a universal gate capable of implementing any Boolean function.
Any linear circuit reduced to a current source (I_n) in parallel with a resistance (R_n).
A logic gate that outputs the complement of its input.
Negative Temperature Coefficient resistor whose resistance decreases with temperature.
Nested Vectored Interrupt Controller on Cortex-M providing configurable priorities, nesting, and hardware-vectored entry.
Half the sampling rate (f_s/2); the highest frequency representable in a sampled signal.
Minimum sampling rate required to represent a bandlimited signal: 2 × f_max.
Factor of 2 in frequency; on logarithmic frequency plots, octaves appear as equal widths.
Oven-Controlled Crystal Oscillator — crystal in a temperature-controlled oven for excellent frequency stability.
SI unit of electrical resistance.
The fundamental relationship between voltage, current, and resistance.
Output Third-Order Intercept Point — theoretical output level where third-order intermodulation equals fundamental.
An operational amplifier — a high-gain differential amplifier used as a universal analog building block with external feedback.
The voltage measured across a source's terminals when no load is connected.
A logic output with only a pull-down transistor, requiring an external pull-up for the HIGH level.
GPIO mode where the pin can only pull LOW actively and floats HIGH, requiring an external pull-up resistor.
The gain of an op-amp without feedback, typically 100,000 V/V or more at DC.
Non-volatile configuration bits controlling MCU behavior such as brownout threshold, debug access, and flash protection.
A logic gate that outputs 1 when any input is 1.
Coupling device between the circuit under test and the oscilloscope input.
Over-The-Air wireless firmware update allowing field devices to receive new firmware without physical connection.
The impedance a circuit presents at its output terminals.
AC voltage variation superimposed on the DC output of a switching regulator.
Sampling at a rate much higher than Nyquist; spreads quantization noise across wider bandwidth and enables noise shaping.
Components connected across the same two nodes so that they share the same voltage.
Unintended capacitance present between conductors, component leads, PCB traces, and other structures.
Unintended inductance in component leads, wires, and PCB traces.
Optimal equiripple method for FIR filter design minimizing maximum error in passband and stopband.
The series transistor in a linear regulator whose resistance adjusts to maintain constant output voltage.
Planar antenna with a conductor on a dielectric substrate over a ground plane; compact and easy to fabricate.
Signal attenuation during propagation including free-space spreading, absorption, and scattering.
Pulse Code Modulation — standard digital audio encoding where samples are quantized to discrete levels.
Pulse Density Modulation — encoding analog information as pulse density in a bitstream; output of 1-bit delta-sigma modulators.
Power Distribution Network — the complete power delivery path from regulator to transistors.
Cortex-M exception used for deferring processing to lower priority, commonly used by RTOS for context switching.
Mechanism enabling or disabling individual peripheral clocks to save power; peripheral registers are inaccessible while gated.
Pulse frequency modulation — a light-load operating mode where switching frequency reduces to maintain efficiency.
48 V DC supplied to condenser microphones through balanced audio cables; not needed for dynamic microphones.
The stability margin — difference between actual phase and 360° at the frequency where loop gain equals unity.
Random fluctuations in oscillator phase; expressed in dBc/Hz at a specific offset frequency.
Antenna array with electronically controlled phase per element to steer the beam without mechanical movement.
Generation of voltage from mechanical stress in certain materials.
Diode with thick intrinsic region behaving as a variable resistor controlled by bias current; used in RF switches.
The functional label of an IC pin (e.g., CLK, RESET, VCC).
The physical location identifier of an IC pin on the package.
The FPGA design step assigning logic to physical locations and connecting them.
Phase-Locked Loop — a feedback circuit synchronizing output frequency with a reference.
The directional convention for voltage measurement.
Orientation of the electric field in an electromagnetic wave; can be linear, circular, or elliptical.
A frequency in a transfer function that contributes -20 dB/decade roll-off and up to -90° of phase shift.
A connection point in a hierarchical schematic that links a sub-sheet to the level above.
Feedback where the returned signal reinforces the input, causing output to diverge. Used in oscillators and latches.
Capturing crash data in non-volatile memory so fault information survives reset for later analysis.
A three-terminal variable resistor with an adjustable wiper contact.
Inductor core made from iron particles with insulating gaps between them.
High-output-power RF amplifier; often nonlinear (Class C, D) for efficiency.
An accounting of all power sources, conversions, and dissipation in a system.
Reduction in a component's maximum allowable power dissipation at temperatures above a specified threshold.
The ratio of real power to apparent power.
Schematic symbols (VCC, VDD, 3V3, 5V, GND) representing global power connections.
The maximum continuous power a component can dissipate at a specified ambient temperature without exceeding its maximum operating temperature.
Normalized spectral power per unit bandwidth (V²/Hz); independent of FFT length.
A measure of ratio.
High-frequency signal boost at the transmitter to compensate for channel attenuation.
First active amplification stage in a signal chain, critical for establishing system noise performance.
The consistency of repeated measurements.
A counter used to divide a clock frequency by a fixed amount.
Bandpass filter before an RF amplifier to reject out-of-band signals.
Cortex-M register that disables all configurable interrupts when set; BASEPRI is more selective.
An encoder that outputs the binary code of the highest-priority active input.
RTOS pathology where a low-priority task holding a resource blocks a high-priority task while medium-priority tasks run.
The distortion introduced by a measurement probe's input impedance (resistive and capacitive) on the circuit being measured.
A component whose resistance increases with temperature.
A resistor connected to supply voltage to establish the HIGH level for open-drain outputs.
Pulse-Width Modulation — generating analog-like output by toggling a digital pin with variable duty cycle at fixed frequency.
The DC operating point of a transistor, determined by the bias circuit.
A measure of how selective a resonant circuit or filter is, with higher Q meaning narrower bandwidth.
Difference between the actual analog value and the nearest quantized level.
Quantization error treated as additive noise when signals are large enough to randomize the error.
The current drawn by a circuit when no signal is applied and no load is driven.
The on-resistance of a MOSFET when fully enhanced, a key parameter for switching efficiency.
Concurrency bug where outcome depends on timing of access to shared data across execution contexts.
Plot of relative field strength or power radiated by an antenna in all directions.
Equivalent resistance representing power radiated by an antenna.
An op-amp whose output can swing close to both supply rails, typically within 50-200 mV.
Small-scale fading where multipath components cause rapid signal variation following a Rayleigh distribution.
Power that cycles back and forth between source and reactive components (capacitors, inductors) without performing net work.
Register access sequence that is not atomic on shared registers and can lose updates if interrupted.
The power actually dissipated as heat or converted to useful work, measured in watts.
Meeting timing deadlines predictably — not necessarily fast, but deterministic and bounded-latency.
Analog low-pass filter removing spectral images in DAC output, converting the staircase to smooth analog.
The unique identifier for each component on a schematic and PCB: R1, C2, U3, Q4, etc.
The assumed direction of current flow or voltage polarity assigned during circuit analysis.
The node assigned zero volts in nodal analysis.
Complex number describing reflected wave magnitude and phase; Γ = (Z_L - Z₀) / (Z_L + Z₀).
A group of flip-flops sharing a common clock, storing a multi-bit word.
How well a voltage source maintains its output under varying load conditions.
Address in the vector table where the CPU begins execution after reset.
The smallest change in a measured quantity that an instrument can display.
The frequency at which an LC circuit oscillates with maximum amplitude.
Loss in dB of reflected signal power; higher return loss indicates better impedance matching.
Using a series or parallel diode to block current if the supply is connected backwards.
The time during which a forward-conducting diode continues to conduct briefly in reverse while stored charge is swept out.
Manual modifications to a PCB after assembly: bodge wires, component swaps, cut traces.
Damped oscillation in a step response, indicating marginal stability or underdamped poles.
AC current superimposed on DC current flowing through a capacitor.
Open instruction set architecture with modular extensions, growing rapidly as an alternative to ARM.
The time for an output to transition from 10% to 90% of its final value in response to a step input.
The effective value of a time-varying signal.
A UART electrical standard using ±3 to ±15 V signal levels.
A differential serial standard supporting multi-drop networks over long distances.
Register Transfer Level — the abstraction level describing data storage and movement between registers.
Inexpensive software-defined radio dongle based on RTL2832U chip covering 24 MHz to 1.8 GHz.
Real-Time Operating System providing preemptive multitasking, scheduling, and synchronization primitives.
Scattering parameters measured by network analyzers describing how RF energy scatters at device ports.
Sony/Philips Digital Interface — consumer digital audio interface carrying PCM on coaxial or optical connection.
The most common active filter topology, using a single op-amp in non-inverting configuration.
Circuit that samples an analog signal and holds the value during conversion; fundamental ADC operation.
Successive Approximation Register ADC using binary search to converge on input voltage; fast and common in MCUs.
The current at which an inductor's core can no longer store additional magnetic energy, causing inductance to drop.
The BJT operating region where both junctions are forward biased and the transistor acts as a low-impedance switch.
Surface Acoustic Wave filter using acoustic waves on a piezoelectric substrate; compact, used up to 3 GHz.
A diode with a metal-semiconductor junction exhibiting lower forward voltage and faster switching than conventional junction diodes.
Software-Defined Radio — radio system where filtering and demodulation traditionally done in hardware is performed in software.
A destructive failure mode where localized heating causes current focusing in high-voltage BJTs.
Receiver's ability to reject signals outside the desired frequency range.
Power dissipation within a component raising its own temperature, changing its electrical parameters.
The frequency at which a capacitor's ESL resonates with its capacitance, causing impedance to reach a minimum.
RTOS synchronization primitive — binary semaphores signal events, counting semaphores track available resources.
Debug mechanism allowing target MCU to call host-side functions via breakpoint; slow but useful for development.
A low-value precision resistor placed in a current path so that the voltage drop across it indicates the current flowing.
Minimum signal level a receiver can detect and process with acceptable performance.
A non-inverting buck-boost topology producing output voltage above or below input with same polarity.
Serializer-deserializer — dedicated high-speed transceiver blocks for multi-gigabit communication.
Components connected end-to-end so that the same current flows through each.
A resistor at the driver matching line impedance to prevent reflections.
The minimum time data must be stable before the clock edge for reliable capture.
Spurious-Free Dynamic Range — ratio between the signal and largest spurious component.
Inductor with a magnetic structure that contains the magnetic field, reducing radiated interference and susceptibility to external fields.
A register where data moves one position per clock cycle through cascaded flip-flops.
Bridge driver fault where both switches are ON simultaneously, shorting the supply rail; prevented by dead-time insertion.
The current that flows when a source's output terminals are connected together.
Random noise caused by the discrete nature of charge carriers crossing a barrier, proportional to DC current.
A two-terminal voltage reference that sinks current to maintain a fixed voltage.
Low-value resistor used inside ammeters and current-sense circuits to convert current into a measurable voltage.
Standard multipliers for units: tera (10¹²), giga (10⁹), mega (10⁶), kilo (10³), milli (10⁻³), micro (10⁻⁶), nano (10⁻⁹), pico (10⁻¹²), femto (10⁻¹⁵).
The reference point for signal voltages in a circuit.
Signal-to-Noise-and-Distortion ratio — the most comprehensive single metric for converter performance.
High-frequency phenomenon where current flows only in a thin surface layer of a conductor.
The difference between required and actual signal arrival time; positive means constraint is met.
The maximum rate at which an op-amp output can change voltage, typically expressed in V/µs.
Linear circuit analysis describing device response to small AC signals around a DC operating point.
Three or four digit code: for a 3-digit code, the first two digits are significant and the third is the exponent.
Graphical tool mapping complex impedance to reflection coefficient for matching network design.
Signal-to-noise ratio — the ratio of signal power to noise power, usually in decibels.
An RC or RCD network that absorbs energy from switching transients, reducing voltage spikes and ringing.
Safe Operating Area — the I-V region where a transistor can safely operate without exceeding voltage, current, or power limits.
A circuit feature that gradually ramps output voltage during startup to limit inrush current.
The process of "turning off" independent sources to find equivalent resistance: voltage sources become short circuits; current sources become open circuits.
A source resistor in a MOSFET amplifier providing stabilizing feedback, analogous to emitter degeneration.
A MOSFET buffer with unity voltage gain and low output impedance, also called common drain.
Energy spread across frequency bins when a signal's frequency doesn't fall exactly on a bin center.
Time-frequency representation showing how spectral content changes over time.
Test instrument displaying signal power versus frequency for RF troubleshooting and characterization.
Serial Peripheral Interface — a synchronous, full-duplex, master-slave serial bus.
Synchronous full-duplex multi-slave bus where master drives clock; CPOL and CPHA settings must match between devices.
The simplest memory element from two cross-coupled gates with Set and Reset inputs.
Static RAM used for runtime variables, stack, and heap on MCUs; volatile, no refresh required, typically 4–256 KB.
Simultaneous Switching Output — number of pins switching at once, affecting power integrity.
Static Timing Analysis — automated timing verification by analyzing all paths without simulation.
Condition where the stack grows past its allocated region into adjacent memory, causing silent corruption without default fault.
Assembly routine running before main() that loads the vector table, copies .data, zeros .bss, and initializes clocks.
A condition where the output should remain constant but momentarily produces the opposite value.
A voltage source with low output impedance, meaning its voltage barely changes when load current varies.
The delay caused by excess base charge that must be removed before a saturated BJT can turn off.
A PCB trace between two ground planes providing controlled impedance and field containment.
Exponential drain current below threshold voltage in a MOSFET, exploited in ultra-low-power design.
Very high-capacitance component (farads to hundreds of farads) used for energy storage and extended holdup time.
Receiver architecture using mixers to downconvert RF to intermediate frequencies for easier filtering.
Simple main loop polling sensors, updating state, and driving outputs in fixed sequence without interrupts or RTOS.
In mesh analysis, a combined loop formed when a current source appears in a branch shared by two meshes.
In nodal analysis, a boundary drawn around a voltage source and its two adjacent nodes, allowing KCL to be applied to the combined region.
The principle that in a linear circuit, the total response equals the sum of the responses due to each independent source acting alone.
2-wire debug interface replacing JTAG on Cortex-M with same functionality and fewer pins.
The highest-noise node in a switching regulator, at the junction between the switch and inductor.
Optional third SWD wire carrying trace output from ITM and ETM.
A counter where all flip-flops are clocked simultaneously.
Converting an HDL description into a netlist of logic elements.
Built-in 24-bit Cortex-M timer generating periodic interrupts, commonly used as RTOS tick source.
A flip-flop that toggles its output when T input is 1.
A resonant LC circuit that stores energy by oscillating between the electric field of the capacitor and the magnetic field of the inductor.
Polarized capacitor with high volumetric efficiency.
Time Division Multiplexing — extension of I2S for multiple audio channels sharing a single serial data line.
Time Domain Reflectometry — measurement using short pulses to characterize transmission lines and locate discontinuities.
Coupled differential equations describing voltage and current on a transmission line; foundation of transmission line theory.
The change in a component's value per degree Celsius, usually expressed in ppm/°C.
Non-synthesizable HDL code that drives a design with stimulus and checks outputs.
Total Harmonic Distortion — ratio of harmonic distortion power to fundamental signal power.
Total Harmonic Distortion plus Noise — combined measure of all signal degradations.
Imaging device that maps surface temperatures across a PCB or system.
Heat transfer between physically adjacent components.
Temperature variation across a PCB causing different components to operate at different temperatures.
Interface material applied between a component and heatsink to fill microscopic air gaps and reduce thermal resistance.
Resistance to heat flow, analogous to electrical resistance.
A positive feedback loop where increased temperature causes increased current (or power), which further increases temperature.
A protection circuit that disables a device if junction temperature exceeds a safe limit.
kT/q, approximately 26 mV at room temperature, appearing throughout semiconductor equations.
The most common SMD resistor type.
Precision SMD resistor with tight tolerance (0.1% or better), excellent tempco, and low noise.
Marking system where the first two digits are significant and the third is a power-of-ten multiplier in picofarads.
Any linear circuit reduced to a voltage source (V_th) in series with a resistance (R_th).
The characteristic response time of an RC or RL circuit.
The iterative process of modifying a design until all timing constraints are met.
The allowable deviation of a component's actual value from its nominal value, expressed as a percentage.
The accumulated uncertainty when multiple components' tolerances combine in a circuit.
Optical digital audio interface using LED/photodiode coupling; immune to ground loops.
Triangular Probability Density Function dither with ±1 LSB peak; completely eliminates quantization distortion.
The ratio of output current change to input voltage change, a key gain parameter for transistors.
The mathematical ratio of output to input as a function of frequency, fully describing a linear circuit's behavior.
A brief, fast-changing voltage or current event.
A conductor pair with distributed L and C causing reflection and wave effects at high frequencies.
Oscilloscope feature that synchronizes the display to a specific event on the waveform, producing a stable, readable display.
The MOSFET operating region where it behaves as a voltage-controlled resistor.
A table listing every input combination and corresponding output for a logic function.
Transistor-Transistor Logic — a logic family built from bipolar transistors.
A transient voltage suppressor diode designed to absorb large transient energy pulses with well-defined clamping voltage.
Two flip-flops in series for safely synchronizing signals between clock domains.
Universal Asynchronous Receiver-Transmitter — an asynchronous serial interface without a dedicated clock.
Point-to-point asynchronous serial interface with no shared clock, standard for debug consoles.
Power factor of 1, meaning voltage and current are perfectly in phase.
Inductor with an open magnetic path that allows the magnetic field to radiate.
USB Communications Device Class making an MCU appear as a virtual serial port to the host computer.
Host-driven process of discovering and configuring a USB device through control transfers and descriptor exchange.
USB Human Interface Device class for keyboards, mice, and custom reports; requires no driver installation on major OSes.
A diode whose junction capacitance varies with reverse voltage, used for frequency tuning and modulation.
Voltage Controlled Oscillator — output frequency controlled by input voltage.
Array of 32-bit addresses at the start of flash containing initial stack pointer and all interrupt handler addresses.
Ratio of signal propagation velocity in a cable to the speed of light; typically 0.66 to 0.85.
A hardware description language for designing and simulating digital circuits.
A hardware description language for designing and simulating digital circuits.
The condition in a negative-feedback op-amp circuit where both inputs are at effectively the same voltage.
Vector Network Analyzer — instrument measuring magnitude and phase of S-parameters for impedance and filter characterization.
C qualifier preventing the compiler from caching a variable in registers; required for ISR-shared and hardware-mapped variables but does not provide atomicity.
SI unit of electric potential difference.
The change in a component's value with applied voltage.
A network (typically two resistors in series) that produces an output voltage proportional to the input voltage.
The standard BJT biasing topology using a resistor divider to set base voltage and an emitter resistor to stabilize collector current.
The available voltage range for signal swing between supply rails and saturation/cutoff limits.
A circuit producing a precise, stable voltage used as a comparison standard in regulators, ADCs, and measurement.
Voltage Standing Wave Ratio — ratio of voltage maximum to minimum on a transmission line indicating match quality.
A timer that resets a system if it fails to complete a sequence within bounded time.
SI unit of power.
Unit of energy.
Metallic pipe structure for guiding electromagnetic waves at microwave and millimeter-wave frequencies.
Variable time-frequency transform with good time resolution at high frequencies and good frequency resolution at low.
Worst-Case Execution Time — the maximum time a code path can take including all delays; the only time that matters for real-time guarantees.
Broadband power divider using quarter-wave lines and termination resistor; good isolation and matched ports.
Taper applied to finite-length signal blocks to reduce spectral leakage at the cost of frequency resolution.
The moving contact in a potentiometer that slides along the resistive element, creating a variable voltage divider.
Precision resistor made by winding resistance wire on a form.
Class II ceramic dielectric rated for -55°C to +85°C with ±15% capacitance variation over temperature.
Class II ceramic dielectric rated for -55°C to +125°C with ±15% capacitance variation over temperature.
A logic gate that outputs 1 when inputs differ.
Class III ceramic dielectric with very high capacitance density but terrible stability: +22% / -82% over temperature range.
Directional antenna with driven element, reflector, and directors providing high gain.
A diode designed to operate in reverse breakdown at a specific voltage, used for voltage references and simple regulators.
A simple voltage regulator consisting of a Zener diode fed through a current-limiting resistor.
Modern embedded RTOS with device tree, driver framework, networking, and Bluetooth support.
A frequency in a transfer function that contributes +20 dB/decade gain and up to +90° of phase advance.
Receiver downconverting directly to baseband; eliminates image problems but introduces DC offset.
Simplest DAC reconstruction holding each sample value until the next; produces staircase with sinc-shaped frequency response.
